text: North Korea is best known for its
nuclear ambitions its effort to build a
missile that could reach the continental
United States and the unpredictability
of its current leader kim jong on it
also has a history of holding American
citizens captive including otto warmbier
the american student who was detained
for 17 months and released in a coma on
june 13th he died six days later at
least 16 Americans have been arrested in
North Korea since 1996 three are still
in custody each one of their situations
is unique but there are some common
threads when it comes to how and when
the North Koreans take Americans into
custody like warm beer summer tourists
others are Christian missionaries or
scholars or human rights activists or
even journalists the detentions can come
at times of high tension between North
Korea and the international community
but often times the arrests seem
arbitrary otto warmbier was arrested
three days before North Korea claimed
that it had detonated its first hydrogen
bomb
Tony kim and kim hak-sun were arrested
during the latest sequence of missile
tests between April and June 2017 Kim
Dong troll was arrested while North
Korea was under pressure at the United
Nations regarding violations of human
rights we don't know very much about how
the North Korea's judiciary works but we
know it works quickly the crimes the
Americans have been charged with have
included unauthorized interactions with
locals carrying out religious activities
spying or in the case of otto warmbier
stealing a propaganda poster
seems like this of American detainees
presented before the camera are common
[Music]
never should have allowed myself to be a
lord in the United States administration
to commit a crime in this country otto
warmbier was ultimately sentenced to 15
years of hard labor for stealing that
political propaganda poster Kim Dong
troll was sentenced to 10 years of hard
labor for alleged espionage aijalon
Molly Gomez was sentenced to eight years
for illegal entry into the country it's
almost impossible to know what North
Korea expects to get by detaining
American citizens one theory is as
leverage in negotiations over sanctions
others believe that these hostages are
taken to reinforce President Kim's
persona as an all-powerful leader
forcing American dignitaries to come
visit to negotiated detainees release
can be pretext for opening a diplomatic
channel frequently that detainees are
used for propaganda purposes for obvious
reasons the Department of State warns US
citizens not to travel in North Korea
but experts estimate that hundreds of
Americans still visit the country every
year Congress is considering legislation
that would make such visits illegal
you
[Music]
